topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Maya Prohovnik, her role leading podcast product at Spotify, and Anchor’s impact on podcast hosting and creation. Maya and Lenny set up the conversation’s focus on product leadership lessons and early Anchor stories.

topics.title: Dogfooding through making multiple podcasts
topics.summary: Maya explains why she personally makes podcasts to understand creators, detailing four shows (Stephen King, Big Brother, a niche book podcast, and parenting). Key insight: firsthand creator experience reveals emotional and practical barriers that data alone can’t show.

topics.title: Operationalizing dogfooding across the product team
topics.summary: Maya shares tactics to make dogfooding real: celebrating teammates who create, incorporating creation into offsites, listening to team podcasts, and offering a practical “how to start” playbook. She also describes her habit of persuading people to start podcasts as a growth lever.

topics.title: Balancing gut instinct with data
topics.summary: Maya discusses how product has become overly “scientific” and why intuition should be treated as a valid data point, especially when building for delight. She outlines when to use different kinds of data and how leaders must justify gut calls with experience, user stories, and clear reasoning.

topics.title: Anchor 1.0 to 2.0: pivot despite good metrics
topics.summary: Maya recounts the difficult decision to move away from a beloved, retained social-audio product because it wouldn’t reach Anchor’s mission-scale ambitions. Lesson: don’t overbuild for the loud 20%; be willing to “kill your darlings” to serve the broader 80% and long-term vision.

topics.title: Anchor 2.0 to podcasting: embracing user demand
topics.summary: After resisting “podcast” framing, Anchor tested exporting/distribution and discovered it triggered hockey-stick growth, prompting a rebuild around RSS and publishing. Lesson: stay flexible—mission can be fixed while tactics and positioning remain mutable; small tests can reveal existential growth levers.

topics.title: Unscalable distribution hack: interns submit to Apple
topics.summary: Maya explains Anchor’s “one-button distribution” illusion: interns manually created Apple IDs and submitted podcasts to reduce friction before automation existed. Key insight: remarkable, friction-killing experiences drive rapid adoption; “build things that don’t scale” can unlock early market share.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Lenny reads an ad for LinkedIn Ads, highlighting B2B targeting, measurement, and a $100 campaign credit offer.

topics.title: Making the Spotify acquisition work
topics.summary: Maya attributes Anchor’s successful integration to cultural fit, shared vision, and proactive internal marketing to stay visible and valuable as strategies evolved. She emphasizes adaptability—embracing shifts while keeping the overarching mission constant.

topics.title: Keeping a startup pace inside Spotify
topics.summary: Maya describes how Anchor preserved its startup identity via explicit core values (including “move fast”) and leadership reinforcement from Spotify’s CEO encouraging them to teach speed to the broader org. She notes inevitable slowing with scale but stresses maintaining the DNA intentionally.
